Context: 1. Sixty percent of the passengers on a train are travelling for business while others travel for leisure. Business travelers tend to use the train’s WIFI system more often (80% of the time compared with 50% for leisure travelers).
Q1: a. What is the chance that a randomly selected passenger uses the WIFI system?
Q2: b. What is the chance that a WIFI user is travelling for business
Q3: c. What is the chance that someone not using WIFI is travelling for leisure?

Context: 2. Some states have recently initiated programs to randomly test high school athletes for possible use of anabolic steroids after concerns arose about the health of the athletes and fairness in the sports. Critics of the programs say that the amount of money spent on testing isn’t worth it, since only 1 in 2000 high school athletes actually use steroids to enhance their performance.  The test used does have a 97.3% chance of being positive when an athlete uses steroids and a 98.4% chance of showing a negative result when an athlete is not using steroids.
Q1: a. What is the chance that the test is negative when an athlete is using steroids?
Q2: b. An athlete tests positive.  What is the chance that he really is using steroids?

Context: 3. 30% of twins are identical, 70% are fraternal and 52% of all births are boys.
Q1: a. What is the chance that the next pair of twins born at Hershey Medical Center hospitals is a BB pair?
Q2: b. If the next pair of twins are a BB pair, what is the chance they are identical?

Context: 4. Thirty percent of the customers at a movie theater are youth under 18 years old, 60% are adults, and 10% are seniors.  Also, 30% of the youth purchase popcorn before the movie compared to 20% of the adults and 10% of the seniors.
Q1: a. A customer is randomly selected, what is the probability that they purchase popcorn?
Q2: b. A customer who purchased popcorn is randomly selected.  What is the chance it was a senior?
